subcommands.name: neard amend-genesis
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Amend a genesis/records file created by `dump-state`

Usage: neard amend-genesis [OPTIONS] --genesis-file-in <GENESIS_FILE_IN> --genesis-file-out <GENESIS_FILE_OUT> --records-file-in <RECORDS_FILE_IN> --records-file-out <RECORDS_FILE_OUT> --validators <VALIDATORS>

Options:
      --genesis-file-in <GENESIS_FILE_IN>
          path to the input genesis file
      --genesis-file-out <GENESIS_FILE_OUT>
          path to the output genesis file
      --records-file-in <RECORDS_FILE_IN>
          path to the input records file. Note that right now this must be provided, and this command will not work with a genesis file that itself contains the records
      --records-file-out <RECORDS_FILE_OUT>
          path to the output records file
      --validators <VALIDATORS>
          path to a JSON list of AccountInfos representing the validators to put in the output genesis state. These are JSON maps of the form { "account_id": <ACCOUNT_ID>, "public_key": <PUBLIC_KEY>, "amount": <STAKE>, }
      --extra-records <EXTRA_RECORDS>
          path to extra records to add to the output state. Right now only Accounts and AccessKey records are supported, and any added accounts must have zero `code_hash`
      --chain-id <CHAIN_ID>
          chain ID to set on the output genesis
      --protocol-version <PROTOCOL_VERSION>
          protocol version to set on the output genesis
      --num-seats <NUM_SEATS>
          num_seats to set in the output genesis file
      --epoch-length <EPOCH_LENGTH>
          epoch length to set in the output genesis file
      --transaction-validity-period <TRANSACTION_VALIDITY_PERIOD>
          transaction_validity_period to set in the output genesis file
      --block-producer-kickout-threshold <BLOCK_PRODUCER_KICKOUT_THRESHOLD>
          block_producer_kickout_threshold to set in the output genesis file
      --chunk-producer-kickout-threshold <CHUNK_PRODUCER_KICKOUT_THRESHOLD>
          chunk_producer_kickout_threshold to set in the output genesis file
      --chunk-validator-only-kickout-threshold <CHUNK_VALIDATOR_ONLY_KICKOUT_THRESHOLD>
          chunk_validator_only_kickout_threshold to set in the output genesis file
      --protocol-reward-rate <PROTOCOL_REWARD_RATE>
          protocol_reward_rate to set in the output genesis file. Give a ratio here (e.g. "1/10")
      --max-inflation-rate <MAX_INFLATION_RATE>
          maximum inflation to se in the output genesis file. Give a ratio here (e.g. "1/10")
      --shard-layout-file <SHARD_LAYOUT_FILE>
          optional file that should contain a JSON-serialized shard layout
      --num-bytes-account <NUM_BYTES_ACCOUNT>
          runtime fees config `num_bytes_account` value. Used to initialize the `storage_usage` field on accounts in the output state
      --num-extra-bytes-record <NUM_EXTRA_BYTES_RECORD>
          runtime fees config `num_extra_bytes_record` value. Used to initialize the `storage_usage` field on accounts in the output state
      --gas-limit <GAS_LIMIT>
          initial gas limit to set in the output genesis file
      --min-gas-price <MIN_GAS_PRICE>
          min_gas_price to set in the output genesis file
      --max-gas-price <MAX_GAS_PRICE>
          max_gas_price to set in the output genesis file
  -h, --help
          Print help

subcommands.name: neard cold-store check-state-root
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Traverse trie and check that every node is in cold db. Can start from given state_root or compute previous roots for every chunk in provided block and use them as starting point. You can provide maximum depth and/or maximum number of vertices to traverse for each root. Trie is traversed using DFS with randomly shuffled kids for every node

Usage: neard cold-store check-state-root [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

Commands:
  height  
  hash    
  help    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
      --max-depth <MAX_DEPTH>  Maximum depth (measured in number of nodes, not trie key length) for checking trie
      --max-count <MAX_COUNT>  Maximum number of nodes checked for each state_root
  -h, --help                   Print help

subcommands.name: neard cold-store prepare-hot
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Prepare a hot db from a rpc db. This command will update the db kind in the db and perform some sanity checks to make sure this db is suitable for migration to split storage. This command expects the following preconditions: - config.store.path points to an existing database with kind Hot or Archive - config.cold_store.path points to an existing database with kind Cold - store_relative_path points to an existing database with kind Rpc

Usage: neard cold-store prepare-hot --store-relative-path <STORE_RELATIVE_PATH>

Options:
  -s, --store-relative-path <STORE_RELATIVE_PATH>
          The relative path to the rpc store that will be converted to a hot store. The path should be relative to the home_dir e.g. hot_data
  -h, --help
          Print help
subcommands.description: Prepare a hot db from a rpc db.

Options:

subcommands.description: Modifies cold db from config to be considered not initialized.

options.description: By default state viewer opens rocks DB in the read only mode.

subcommands.name: neard cold-store
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Testing tool for cold storage

Usage: neard cold-store [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

Commands:
  open              Open NodeStorage and check that is has cold storage
  head              Open NodeStorage and print cold head, hot head and hot final head
  copy-next-blocks  Copy n blocks to cold storage and update cold HEAD. One by one. Updating of HEAD happens in every iteration
  copy-all-blocks   Copy all blocks to cold storage and update cold HEAD
  prepare-hot       Prepare a hot db from a rpc db. This command will update the db kind in the db and perform some sanity checks to make sure this db is suitable for migration to split storage. This command expects the following preconditions: - config.store.path points to an existing database with kind Hot or Archive - config.cold_store.path points to an existing database with kind Cold - store_relative_path points to an existing database with kind Rpc
  check-state-root  Traverse trie and check that every node is in cold db. Can start from given state_root or compute previous roots for every chunk in provided block and use them as starting point. You can provide maximum depth and/or maximum number of vertices to traverse for each root. Trie is traversed using DFS with randomly shuffled kids for every node
  reset-cold        Modifies cold db from config to be considered not initialized. Doesn't actually delete any data, except for HEAD and COLD_HEAD in BlockMisc
  help              Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -w, --readwrite  By default state viewer opens rocks DB in the read only mode, which allows it to run multiple instances in parallel and be sure that no unintended changes get written to the DB
  -h, --help       Print help

subcommands.name: neard database
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Set of commands to run on database

Usage: neard database <COMMAND>

Commands:
  analyze-data-size-distribution  Analyze data size distribution in RocksDB
  analyze-gas-usage               Analyze gas usage in a chosen sequence of blocks
  change-db-kind                  Change DbKind of hot or cold db
  compact-database                Run SST file compaction on database
  drop-column                     Drop a column from the database
  make-snapshot                   Make snapshot of the database
  run-migrations                  Run migrations
  state-perf                      Run performance test for State column reads. Uses RocksDB data specified via --home argument
  load-mem-trie                   Loads an in-memory trie for research purposes
  split-shard-trie                Splits the given shard on the given boundary account and prints approximate RAM usage of the child shards
  find-boundary-account           Find a split account for the given shard based on `memory_usage` stored in trie nodes
  archival-data-loss-recovery     Recover the archival data that was lost during resharding
  write-crypto-hash               Write CryptoHash to DB
  high-load-stats                 Outputs stats that are needed to analyze high load for a block range and account
  analyze-delayed-receipt         Analyze delayed receipts in a piece of history of the blockchain to understand congestion of each shard
  analyze-contract-sizes          Analyze size of contracts present in the current state
  set-version                     Manually set database version
  help                            Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -h, --help  Print help

subcommands.raw_help_text:
Flat storage related tooling

Usage: neard flat-storage <COMMAND>

Commands:
  view                      View the current state of flat storage
  reset                     Reset the flat storage state (remove all the contents)
  verify                    Verify flat storage state (it can take up to couple hours if flat storage is very large)
  set-store-version         Temporary command to set the store version (useful as long flat storage is enabled only during nightly with separate DB version)
  construct-trie-from-flat  Construct and store trie in a separate directory from flat storage state for a given shard. The trie is constructed for the block height equal to flat_head
  move-flat-head            Move flat storage head
  resume-resharding         Resume an unfinished Flat storage resharding for a given shard
  help                      Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -h, --help  Print help
subcommands.description: Flat storage related tooling

Path to the JSON list of [`Validator`] structs containing account id and public keys. The path can be relative to `home_dir` or an absolute path. Example of a valid file that sets one validator with 50k tokens: [{ "account_id": "validator0", "public_key": "ed25519:7PGseFbWxvYVgZ89K1uTJKYoKetWs7BJtbyXDzfbAcqX", "amount": 50000000000000000000000000000 }]

subcommands.name: neard fork-network set-validators
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Creates a DB snapshot, then Reads a list of validator accounts from a file Adds validator accounts to the state Creates a genesis file with the new validators

Usage: neard fork-network set-validators [OPTIONS] --validators <VALIDATORS>

Options:
  -s, --state-source <STATE_SOURCE>
          Source of state to be used for the new chain [default: dump]
      --patches-path <PATCHES_PATH>
          Path to patches directory, required when state source is Empty
  -v, --validators <VALIDATORS>
          Path to the JSON list of [`Validator`] structs containing account id and public keys. The path can be relative to `home_dir` or an absolute path. Example of a valid file that sets one validator with 50k tokens: [{ "account_id": "validator0", "public_key": "ed25519:7PGseFbWxvYVgZ89K1uTJKYoKetWs7BJtbyXDzfbAcqX", "amount": 50000000000000000000000000000 }]
  -e, --epoch-length <EPOCH_LENGTH>
          [default: 1000]
      --chain-id <CHAIN_ID>
          Sets the chain id [default: mocknet]
      --genesis-time <GENESIS_TIME>
          Timestamp that should be set in the genesis block. This is required if you want to create a consistent forked network across many machines
      --protocol-version <PROTOCOL_VERSION>
          Genesis protocol version. If not present, the protocol version of the current epoch will be used
      --num-seats <NUM_SEATS>
          Number of validator seats
  -h, --help
          Print help
subcommands.description: Creates a DB snapshot, then reads a list of validator accounts from a file, adds validator accounts to the state, and creates a genesis file with the new validators.

subcommands.name: neard fork-network
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Resets the network into a forked network at the given block height and state

Usage: neard fork-network <COMMAND>

Commands:
  init               Prepares the DB for doing the modifications: * Makes a snapshot. * Finds and persists state roots
  amend-access-keys  Creates a DB snapshot, then Updates the state to ensure every account has a full access key that is known to us
  set-validators     Creates a DB snapshot, then Reads a list of validator accounts from a file Adds validator accounts to the state Creates a genesis file with the new validators
  finalize           Drops unneeded columns
  reset              Recovers from a snapshot. Deletes the snapshot
  help               Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -h, --help  Print help
subcommands.description: Resets the network into a forked network at the given block height and state

subcommands.name: neard init
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Initializes NEAR configuration

Usage: neard init [OPTIONS]

Options:
      --download-genesis
          Download the verified NEAR genesis file automatically
      --download-config [<DOWNLOAD_CONFIG>]
          Download the verified NEAR config file automatically. Can be one of "validator", "rpc", and "archival". If flag is present with no value, defaults to "validator"
      --fast
          Makes block production fast (TESTING ONLY)
      --account-id <ACCOUNT_ID>
          Account ID for the validator key
      --chain-id <CHAIN_ID>
          Chain ID, by default creates new random
      --download-genesis-url <DOWNLOAD_GENESIS_URL>
          Specify a custom download URL for the genesis file
      --download-records-url <DOWNLOAD_RECORDS_URL>
          Specify a custom download URL for the records file
      --download-config-url <DOWNLOAD_CONFIG_URL>
          Specify a custom download URL for the config file
      --genesis <GENESIS>
          Genesis file to use when initializing testnet (including downloading)
      --boot-nodes <BOOT_NODES>
          Initialize boots nodes in <node_key>@<ip_addr> format separated by commas to bootstrap the network and store them in config.json
      --num-shards <NUM_SHARDS>
          Number of shards to initialize the chain with [default: 1]
      --test-seed <TEST_SEED>
          Specify private key generated from seed (TESTING ONLY)
      --max-gas-burnt-view <MAX_GAS_BURNT_VIEW>
          Customize max_gas_burnt_view runtime limit.  If not specified, value from genesis configuration will be taken
      --state-sync-bucket <STATE_SYNC_BUCKET>
          Specify the cloud bucket to use for state sync

          Print help

subcommands.name: neard localnet
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Sets up local configuration with all necessary files (validator key, node key, genesis and config)

Usage: neard localnet [OPTIONS]

Options:
  -s, --shards <SHARDS>
          Number of shards to initialize the localnet with [default: 1]
  -v, --validators <VALIDATORS>
          Number of validators to initialize the localnet with [default: 4]
      --non-validators-archival <NON_VALIDATORS_ARCHIVAL>
          Number of non-validator archival nodes to initialize the localnet with. They are created in addition to the other non-validators. The archival nodes will have split storage (hot + cold) and they will track all shards [default: 0]
      --non-validators-rpc <NON_VALIDATORS_RPC>
          Number of non-validator RPC nodes to initialize the localnet with. They are created in addition to the other non-validators. The RPC nodes will track all shards [default: 0]
  -n, --non-validators <NON_VALIDATORS>
          Number of non-validators to initialize the localnet with. Prefer `--non_validators_archival` and `--non_validators_rpc` to create non-validator nodes configured for the archival and RPC roles [default: 0]
      --prefix <PREFIX>
          Prefix for the directory name for each node with (e.g. ‘node’ results in ‘node0’, ‘node1’, ...) [default: node]
      --tracked-shards <TRACKED_SHARDS>
          Comma separated list of shards to track, the word 'all' to track all shards or the word 'none' to track no shards [default: all]
  -h, --help
          Print help
subcommands.description: Sets up local configuration with all necessary files (validator key, node key, genesis and config)

subcommands.name: neard mirror prepare
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Write a new genesis records file where the public keys have been altered so that this binary can sign transactions when mirroring them from the source chain to the target chain

Usage: neard mirror prepare [OPTIONS] --records-file-in <RECORDS_FILE_IN> --records-file-out <RECORDS_FILE_OUT> --secret-file-out <SECRET_FILE_OUT>

Options:
      --records-file-in <RECORDS_FILE_IN>
          A genesis records file as output by `neard view-state dump-state --stream`
      --records-file-out <RECORDS_FILE_OUT>
          Path to the new records file with updated public keys
      --no-secret
          If this is provided, don't use a secret when mapping public keys to new source chain private keys. This means that anyone will be able to sign transactions for the accounts in the target chain corresponding to accounts in the source chain. If that is okay, then --no-secret will make the code run slightly faster, and you won't have to take care to not lose the secret
      --secret-file-out <SECRET_FILE_OUT>
          Path to the secret. Note that if you don't pass --no-secret, this secret is required to sign transactions for the accounts in the target chain corresponding to accounts in the source chain. This means that if you lose this secret, you will no longer be able to mirror any traffic
  -h, --help
          Print help
subcommands.description: Write a new genesis records file with altered public keys for signing transactions

options.description: Equivalent to passing --secret-file <FILE> where <FILE> is a config that indicates no secret should be used.
Start a NEAR node for the source chain, instead of only using whatever's currently stored in --source-home.
File containing an optional secret as generated by the `prepare` command. Must be provided unless --no-secret is given.
If provided, we will stop after sending transactions coming from this height in the source chain.

subcommands.name: neard mirror run
subcommands.raw_help_text:
initialize a target chain with genesis records from the source chain, and then try to mirror transactions from the source chain to the target chain

Usage: neard mirror run [OPTIONS] --source-home <SOURCE_HOME> --target-home <TARGET_HOME>

Options:
      --source-home <SOURCE_HOME>
          source chain home dir
      --target-home <TARGET_HOME>
          target chain home dir
      --mirror-db-path <MIRROR_DB_PATH>
          mirror database dir
      --secret-file <SECRET_FILE>
          file containing an optional secret as generated by the `prepare` command. Must be provided unless --no-secret is given
      --no-secret
          Equivalent to passing --secret-file <FILE> where <FILE> is a config that indicates no secret should be used. If this is given, and --secret-file is also given and points to a config that does contain a secret, the mirror will refuse to start
      --online-source
          Start a NEAR node for the source chain, instead of only using whatever's currently stored in --source-home
      --stop-height <STOP_HEIGHT>
          If provided, we will stop after sending transactions coming from this height in the source chain
      --config-path <CONFIG_PATH>
          
  -h, --help
          Print help
subcommands.description: Initialize a target chain with genesis records and mirror transactions from the source chain

subcommands.name: neard mirror
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Mirror transactions from a source chain to a test chain with state forked from it, reproducing traffic and state as closely as possible

Usage: neard mirror <COMMAND>

Commands:
  prepare    Write a new genesis records file where the public keys have been altered so that this binary can sign transactions when mirroring them from the source chain to the target chain
  run        initialize a target chain with genesis records from the source chain, and then try to mirror transactions from the source chain to the target chain
  show-keys  Print the secret keys that correspond to source chain public keys
  help       Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -h, --help  Print help
subcommands.description: Mirror transactions from a source chain to a test chain with state forked from it

subcommands.name: neard ping
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Connects to a NEAR node and sends ping messages to the accounts it sends us after the handshake is completed, printing stats to stdout

Usage: neard ping [OPTIONS] --chain-id <CHAIN_ID> --peer <PEER>

Options:
      --chain-id <CHAIN_ID>
          
      --genesis-hash <GENESIS_HASH>
          genesis hash to use in the Handshake we send. This must be provided if --chain-id is not "mainnet" or "testnet"
      --head-height <HEAD_HEIGHT>
          head height to use in the Handshake we send. This must be provided if --chain-id is not "mainnet" or "testnet"
      --protocol-version <PROTOCOL_VERSION>
          Protocol version to advertise in our handshake
      --peer <PEER>
          node public key and socket address in the format {pub key}@{socket addr}. e.g.: ed25519:7PGseFbWxvYVgZ89K1uTJKYoKetWs7BJtbyXDzfbAcqX@127.0.0.1:24567
      --ttl <TTL>
          ttl to set on our Routed messages [default: 100]
      --ping-frequency-millis <PING_FREQUENCY_MILLIS>
          milliseconds to wait between sending pings [default: 1000]
      --account-filter-file <ACCOUNT_FILTER_FILE>
          line-separated list of accounts to filter on. We will only try to send pings to these accounts
      --latencies-csv-file <LATENCIES_CSV_FILE>
          filename to append CSV data to
      --recv-timeout-seconds <RECV_TIMEOUT_SECONDS>
          number of seconds to wait for incoming data before timing out
      --prometheus-addr <PROMETHEUS_ADDR>
          Listen address for prometheus metrics [default: 0.0.0.0:9000]
      --just-handshake
          Just establish a handshake connection and exit without sending pings
  -h, --help
          Print help

subcommands.name: neard run
subcommands.raw_help_text:
Runs NEAR node

Usage: neard run [OPTIONS]

Options:
      --archive
          Configure node to run as archival node which prevents deletion of old blocks.  This is a persistent setting; once client is started as archival node, it cannot be run in non-archival mode
      --boot-nodes <BOOT_NODES>
          Set the boot nodes to bootstrap network from
      --connect-to-reliable-peers-on-startup <CONNECT_TO_RELIABLE_PEERS_ON_STARTUP>

      --min-peers <MIN_PEERS>
          Minimum number of peers to start syncing/producing blocks
      --network-addr <NETWORK_ADDR>
          Customize network listening address (useful for running multiple nodes on the same machine)
      --produce-empty-blocks <PRODUCE_EMPTY_BLOCKS>
          Set this to false to only produce blocks when there are txs or receipts (default true) [possible values: true, false]
      --rpc-addr <RPC_ADDR>
          Customize RPC listening address (useful for running multiple nodes on the same machine).  Ignored if ‘--disable-rpc’ is given
      --rpc-prometheus-addr <RPC_PROMETHEUS_ADDR>
          Export prometheus metrics on an additional listening address, which is useful for having separate access restrictions for the RPC and prometheus endpoints. Ignored if RPC http server is disabled, see 'rpc_addr'
      --disable-rpc
          Disable the RPC endpoint.  This is a no-op on builds which don’t support RPC endpoint
      --telemetry-url <TELEMETRY_URL>
          Customize telemetry url
      --max-gas-burnt-view <MAX_GAS_BURNT_VIEW>
          Customize max_gas_burnt_view runtime limit.  If not specified, either value given at 'init' (i.e. present in config.json) or one from genesis configuration will be taken

options.description: The format of the output. This can be either `full` or `pretty`. The full format will print all the trie nodes and can be rooted anywhere in the trie. The pretty format will only print leaf nodes and must be rooted in the state root but is more human friendly
The hash of the trie node. For format=full this can be any node in the trie. For format=pretty this must the state root node.
The id of the shard, a number between [0-NUM_SHARDS). When looking for particular account you will need to know on which shard it's located
The current shard version based on the shard layout.
The max depth of trie iteration. It's recommended to keep that value small, otherwise the output may be really large.
Limits how many entries are printed to the output
Filters output to only show records of the given type
Skips nodes which AccountId is lexicographically less than `from` (except being a prefix of `from`)
Skips nodes which AccountId is lexicographically greater than `to`

subcommands.name: neard view-state view-trie
subcommands.raw_help_text:
View trie structure

Usage: neard view-state view-trie [OPTIONS] --hash <HASH> --shard-id <SHARD_ID> --shard-version <SHARD_VERSION> --max-depth <MAX_DEPTH>

Options:
      --format <FORMAT>                The format of the output. This can be either `full` or `pretty`. The full format will print all the trie nodes and can be rooted anywhere in the trie. The pretty format will only print leaf nodes and must be rooted in the state root but is more human friendly [default: pretty] [possible values: full, pretty]
      --hash <HASH>                    The hash of the trie node. For format=full this can be any node in the trie. For format=pretty this must the state root node. You can find the state root hash using the `view-state view-chain` command
      --shard-id <SHARD_ID>            The id of the shard, a number between [0-NUM_SHARDS). When looking for particular account you will need to know on which shard it's located
      --shard-version <SHARD_VERSION>  The current shard version based on the shard layout. You can find the shard version by using the `view-state view-chain` command. It's typically equal to 0 for single shard localnet or the most recent near_primitives::shard_layout::ShardLayout for prod
      --max-depth <MAX_DEPTH>          The max depth of trie iteration. It's recommended to keep that value small, otherwise the output may be really large. For format=full this measures depth in terms of number of trie nodes. For format=pretty this measures depth in terms of key nibbles
      --limit <LIMIT>                  Limits how many entries are printed to the output
      --record-type <RECORD_TYPE>      Filters output to only show records of the given type [possible values: account, contract-code, access-key, received-data, postponed-receipt-id, pending-data-count, postponed-receipt, delayed-receipt-or-indices, contract-data, promise-yield-receipt]
      --from <FROM>                    Skips nodes which AccountId is lexicographically less than `from` (except being a prefix of `from`)
      --to <TO>                        Skips nodes which AccountId is lexicographically greater than `to`
  -h, --help                           Print help
subcommands.description: View trie structure.

Tools for manually validating state witnesses.

Second, validate a particular state witness from a file using the `validate` command.

subcommands.name: neard view-state
subcommands.raw_help_text:
View DB state

Usage: neard view-state [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

Commands:
  apply                     Apply block at some height for shard
  apply-chunk               Apply a chunk, even if it's not included in any block on disk
  apply-range               Apply blocks at a range of heights for a single shard
  apply-receipt             Apply a receipt if it occurs in some chunk we know about, even if it's not included in any block on disk
  apply-tx                  Apply a transaction if it occurs in some chunk we know about, even if it's not included in any block on disk
  chain                     Print chain from start_index to end_index
  check-block               Check whether the node has all the blocks up to its head
  chunks                    Looks up a certain chunk
  chunk-apply-stats         View chunk application stats for a chunk
  clear-cache               Clear recoverable data in CachedContractCode column
  contract-accounts         List account names with contracts deployed
  debug-ui                  Run a readonly Debug UI API server so the Debug UI can be used to query this node
  dump-account-storage      Dump contract data in storage of given account to binary file
  dump-code                 Dump deployed contract code of given account to wasm file
  dump-state                Generate a genesis file from the current state of the DB
  dump-state-redis          Writes state to a remote redis server
  dump-tx                   Generate a file that contains all transactions from a block
  epoch-info                Print `EpochInfo` of an epoch given by `--epoch_id` or by `--epoch_height`
  epoch-analysis            Regenerates epoch info based on previous epoch
  partial-chunks            Looks up a certain partial chunk
  receipts                  Looks up a certain receipt
  replay-headers            Replay block headers from chain
  rocksdb-stats             Dump stats for the RocksDB storage
  scan-db-column            Reads all rows of a DB column and deserializes keys and values and prints them
  state                     Iterates over a trie and prints the StateRecords
  state-changes             Dumps or applies StateChanges. Experimental tool for shard shadowing development
  state-parts               Dump or apply state parts
  state-stats               Iterates over the Flat State and prints some statistics. e.g. large accounts, total, average and median size, middle account
  trie-iteration-benchmark  Benchmark how long does it take to iterate the trie
  view-chain                View head of the storage
  view-genesis              View genesis block and chunks built from the config and in the store
  view-trie                 View trie structure
  state-witness             Tools for manually validating state witnesses
  congestion-control        Tools for printing and recalculating the congestion information
  help                      Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -w, --read-write
          By default state viewer opens rocks DB in the read only mode, which allows it to run multiple instances in parallel and be sure that no unintended changes get written to the DB. In case an operation needs to write to caches, a read-write mode may be needed
  -t, --store-temperature <STORE_TEMPERATURE>
          What store temperature should the state viewer open. Allowed values are hot and cold but cold is only available when cold_store is configured. Cold temperature actually means the split store will be used [default: hot]
  -h, --help
          Print help

Enables export of span data using opentelemetry exporters
Enable JSON output of IO events, written to a file
Skips consistency checks of genesis.json upon startup
Sets verbose logging for the given target

name: neard
raw_help_text:
NEAR Protocol Node

Usage: neard [OPTIONS] <COMMAND>

Commands:
  init                    Initializes NEAR configuration
  run                     Runs NEAR node
  localnet                Sets up local configuration with all necessary files (validator key, node key, genesis and config)
  view-state              View DB state
  verify-proof            Verify proofs
  ping                    Connects to a NEAR node and sends ping messages to the accounts it sends us after the handshake is completed, printing stats to stdout
  mirror                  Mirror transactions from a source chain to a test chain with state forked from it, reproducing traffic and state as closely as possible
  amend-genesis           Amend a genesis/records file created by `dump-state`
  cold-store              Testing tool for cold storage
  state-parts             Connects to a NEAR node and sends state parts requests after the handshake is completed
  flat-storage            Flat storage related tooling
  validate-config         validate config files including genesis.json and config.json
  undo-block              reset the head of the chain locally to the prev block of current head
  database                Set of commands to run on database
  fork-network            Resets the network into a forked network at the given block height and state
  state-parts-dump-check  Check completeness of dumped state parts of an epoch
  replay-archive          Replays the blocks in the chain from an archival node
  dump-test-contracts     Placeholder for test contracts subcommand
  dump-epoch-configs      Dump hard-coded epoch configs into JSON files
  help                    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
      --verbose [<target>]
          Sets verbose logging for the given target, or for all targets if no target is given
      --home <HOME>
          Directory for config and data [default: /root/.near]
      --unsafe-fast-startup
          Skips consistency checks of genesis.json (and records.json) upon startup. Let's you start `neard` slightly faster
      --opentelemetry <OPENTELEMETRY>
          Enables export of span data using opentelemetry exporters [default: off] [possible values: off, info, debug, trace]
      --color <COLOR>
          Whether the log needs to be colored [default: auto] [possible values: always, never, auto]
      --log-span-events
          Enable logging of spans. For instance, this prints timestamps of entering and exiting a span, together with the span duration and used/idle CPU time
      --record-io-trace <RECORD_IO_TRACE>
          Enable JSON output of IO events, written to a file
  -h, --help
          Print help
  -V, --version
          Print version
